variant.question: During take-off an aircraft hits a bird. Due to control vibrations a landing must be made immediately. Following this incident the pilot:

options.text: must file a Bird Strike report.
is not obliged to report this incident.
must file an AIR PROX report: the Control Tower having given no warning.
must file an airworthiness report.

variant.question:
If we decided our aircraft requires ditching in the sea/ocean? 
What configuration should your aircraft in

options.text: Gear up/Nose Up
Gear up / Nose Down
Gear Down/ Nose Down
Gear Down/Nose up
The landing site will be at the earliest opportunity.
The landing site can only be the destination aerodrome.
The landing site is irrelevant since the highest priority is to land immediately.
The landing site can only be the alternate aerodrome.

variant.question: Which statement is correct when you considering a ditching situation?

options.text: In case of strong winds, you will try to land into the wind which may put you in a position slightly across the swell.
The aircraft should always land into wind.
The decision about the landing direction should be made shortly before the ditching so that possible changes in the wind direction will be considered.
The aircraft should always land perpendicular to the waves.

variant.question: What is the required configuration for ditching?

options.text: Nose up, gear up.
Nose down, gear up.
Nose up, gear down.
Nose down, gear down.

variant.question: Which option contains the most relevant factor when deciding to make a precautionary landing?

options.text: The choice of landing site should be made at the earliest opportunity.
Precautionary landings should only be made at and alternate aerodrome.
The choice of landing site is irrelevant - landing immediately has the highest priority.
Precautionary landings should only be made at the departiure point or the destination.
The first action should be to inform ATC of the emergency before losing communications.
The only priority is the immediate landing of the helicopter, all other considerations are always secondary.
Landing shall be made as soon as possible regardless of surface and facilities.
Passengers should be briefed.

variant.question:
Following an emergency landing which will need an escape from the aircraft, what will the pilot do?
1. Remain on the runway. 
 2. Clear the runway using the first available taxiway. 
 3. Keep one engine or the APU running in order to maintain the electrical power supply on. 
 4. Turn off all systems.

options.text: 1 and 4.
2 and 3.
2 and 4.
1 and 3.

variant.question: Which of the following situations could lead to the pilot of a light aircraft carrying out a precautionary landing?

options.text: Fuel shortage, deteriorating weather, or approaching darkness.
Deteriorating weather, failure of primary flying controls, or total engine failure.
Lack of situational awareness, total electrics failure, or fire in the cockpit.
Tiredness, total engine failure, or a critically ill passenger.

variant.question: Which of the following should be considered when deciding to ditch an aircraft?

options.text: In strong winds, the landing should be made more into wind and may therefore be slightly across the swell system.
The landing should generally be made perpendicular to the swell.
The decision as to landing direction should be made as late as possible to allow for last-minute changes in the behaviour of the main swell.
The landing should generally be made into wind.

variant.question: During an overwater flight, all engines on a commercial multi-engined jet aircraft fail and you are in a state of emergency. When deciding to make an emergency landing (ditching), which of the following has the highest priority?

options.text: Maintain control of the aircraft.
Make sure that the passengers remain seated.
Instruct all passengers to put on, and inflate, their lifejackets.
Let someone know your plans and needs.

variant.question: Following a heavy mass landing on a short runway, you should pay attention to the

options.text: temperature of the brakes.
temperature of the hydraulic fluid.
pressure of the pneumatic system.
pressure of the hydraulic fluid.

variant.question: In the event that an emergency landing must be initiated:

options.text: Passengers should be advised of what actions they should take as appropriate to the situation.
ATC must be advised about all actions.
The aircraft must be landed as soon as possible, regardless of the appropriateness of the landing area.
We do NOT need to consider the suitability of an airfield or runway, since it is an emergency.

variant.question: Which of the following is the correct attude for an ditching aircraft ?

options.text: Nose attitude Up / Landing Gear Up
Nose attitude Up / Landing Gear Down
Nose attitude Down / Landing Gear Up
Nose attitude Down  / Landing Gear Down

variant.question: What is one main factor to be remembered when considering the ditching of an aircraft?

options.text: On the high seas, it is usually best to ditch parallel to, and on top of the primary swell system, except in high wind conditions.
When deciding to ditch, in any direction, considerations of the wind may be omitted.
On the high seas, it is usually best to ditch in any direction considered necessary, regardless of the sea state.
It is usually best to ditch perpendicular to, and on top of, the primary swell system, regardless of the sea state, except in high wind conditions.

variant.question: When would a pilot consider making a precautionary landing?

options.text: With low fuel, when feeling tired or with the onset of night time.
With an engine failure, main aerodynamic control failure or broken GPS.
With a fire in the cockpit, failure of the main direction indicator or when lost.
With an engine failure or loss of spatial awareness or a minor electrical failure.

variant.question: A single-engine aircraft with an MOPSC of 5 carries out a forced landing in the Sahara. What rescue and survival equipment must be on board?

options.text: One ELT
Megaphone
Crash axe
Two ELT
